cluster_relations.rel_desc: The origins of urban legends are a topic situated within the broader field of modern folklore.
remarks: Relation primarily created to capture that the research topic (origins of urban legends) is contextualized in modern folklore; semantics somewhat inferred.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The origins of urban legends are located in the historical period referred to as ancient times.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Narrative Explanations of the Unknown and Historical Origins

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when stories were used to explain the unknown

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The origins of urban legends are linked to, and part of, the broader context of modern folklore.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ResearchChallenge: tracing these origins is difficult

remarks: Association inferred from surrounding context; modern folklore is not explicitly named in the same sentence as origins.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an academic or scholarly field includes a given subject as one of its research topics.
args.justification: The subject 'modern folklore' is an academic/folklore field and the object 'origins of urban legends' is a research topic within that field; the relation description explicitly frames this as a thematic placement within a broader field.
args.remark: Use this predicate for field/discipline -> topic relations where the topic is studied within the field.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a subject is a research topic within a specified academic or scholarly field.
args.justification: This is the inverse direction of the previous relation: here 'origins of urban legends' (topic) is linked to 'modern folklore' (field) with a contextual research/field-of-study nuance; a topic-to-field predicate is appropriate.
args.remark: Inverse of 'has_research_topic'; keep both for directional clarity in the KG.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the origins or beginnings of a phenomenon can be traced to a particular historical period or time span.
args.justification: The description and hint ('temporal origin') indicate that 'origins of urban legends' are traced back to 'ancient times', which is best modeled as a temporal origin relation rather than a generic association.

Both relations connect an academic/scholarly field ('modern folklore') with one of its research topics ('origins of urban legends'), differing only by direction; they belong to the same conceptual class of field–topic relations.
This relation specifies when the origins of a phenomenon are located ('ancient times'); it is about the temporal starting point of the subject, fitting a temporal-origin class.
Field–topic relations express a conceptual association between an area of study and the subjects it examines, rather than composition, causality, or temporality.
The relation encodes when the origins occur ('ancient times'); this is fundamentally a temporal placement, so it belongs under TEMPORALITY.
